chapters.title: Introduction/Definition
chapters.text: Opportunity cost is defined as the next best alternative that is given up when given a choice/undertaking an activity. In other words, an opportunity cost is the "potential benefit" a person could have derived from using their money in a different venture/investment, from the one that they actually pursued.

chapters.title: Relevance
chapters.text: In economics, it is useful to weigh all outcomes and choose the solution you think is best, and know what you are giving up

chapters.title: Formula
chapters.text: Return from the most profitable investment (what’s lost) / Return from investment selected (what’s gained)

chapters.title: Example
chapters.text: A farmer chooses to plant wheat; the opportunity cost is planting a different crop, or an alternate use of the resources (land and farm equipment). That is, he could have planted a different crop to earn money or leased out his land to earn money. This "potential benefit" is his opportunity cost.
